I can investigate if I know where to look.

messages.text:
someone asked me this before over email, so I happen to have an answer ready :kissing_closed_eyes:

So far, sticking to Julia has allowed us to design an awesome integrated experience. On one hand, implementing a new feature is easy, because it only needs to work with one language. But more importantly, I think that we get a lot of ideas that might not have come up in a multi-language mindset. Examples are <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/pull/720|here>, <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/pull/661|here>, <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/pull/538|here>, and much more <https://www.notion.so/Pluto-jl-a9982e79b7bb4c658e6216c15a9d4cab|here>. Lots of projects demonstrate this, examples are excel, <http://px16.matt.is>, observablehq, LabVIEW, shader programming in unreal engine, lego mindstorms, etc. A smaller problem space can be given a better UX. (In fact, one of our more futuristic ideas is to provide a way for packages to define domain-specific UI, which will be rendered inline instead of code. Examples are a GUI to change a plot layout, a scrubble number instead of a static one, wysiwyg editor for markdown strings, ...) I think that there is still a lot to discover with Julia, since scientific programming is too often done in my least favourite environment: a text editor with a terminal. And I hope that these discoveries get picked up by other projects for other languages!

, observablehq, LabVIEW, shader programming in unreal engine, lego mindstorms, etc. A smaller problem space can be given a better UX. Examples are a GUI to change a plot layout, a scrubble number instead of a static one, wysiwyg editor for markdown strings, ...) I think that there is still a lot to discover with Julia, since scientific programming is too often done in my least favourite environment: a text editor with a terminal. And I hope that these discoveries get picked up by other projects for other languages!

messages.text:
I tried to implement a button similar to `PlutoUI.Button` but with a different label and value:
```begin
	struct Button2
		label::String
		val::String
	end
	function Base.show(io::IO, ::MIME"text/html", button::Button2)
		print(io, """<input type="button" value="$(Markdown.htmlesc(button.label))">""")
	end
	function Base.get(bt::Button2)
		return bt.val
	end
end```
I can verify that the correct `get` method is called, and returns `bt.val` but for some reason the variable still gets assigned `bt.label`. What am I missing?

messages.text:
What is the best way to debug code in a pluto notebook?
What I came up with was:
1. Open the notebook in vscode
2. Search the relevant notebook cell using cmd-s
3. put in a breakpoint there
4. run the whole file with a debugger

elements.text:
What is the best way to debug code in a pluto notebook?
What I came up with was:
Open the notebook in vscode
Search the relevant notebook cell using cmd-s
put in a breakpoint there
run the whole file with a debugger

messages.text: Hi guys, I hope you are doing well. My team and I are writing a Data Science book with code in Julia. We will make the book available online once it is finished, and we would love to have Pluto notebooks of each chapter hosted somewhere so people can explore and test the code by themselves. Does anybody have good recommendations for this? It would be very much appreciated. Thanks in advance!

elements.text: Hi guys, I hope you are doing well. My team and I are writing a Data Science book with code in Julia. We will make the book available online once it is finished, and we would love to have Pluto notebooks of each chapter hosted somewhere so people can explore and test the code by themselves. Does anybody have good recommendations for this? It would be very much appreciated. Thanks in advance!

messages.text: File this under "O for Obvious":  I've been working on a Pluto notebook at a very remote facility that has suboptimal Internet connectivity (low bandwidth and high latency) using Firefox in a VNC session running on a server at the remote facility from a VNC client on my laptop.  During a recent period of unusually sporadic connectedness, progress was extremely slow and painful.  Then it dawned on me (finally!) that I could create a port forwarding tunnel via SSH and connect from the browser on my laptop to the Pluto server running at the remote site through the port forwarding tunnel.  I'm no stranger to port forwarding, but I hadn't realized how beneficial it would be for Pluto notebooks.  It was a complete game changer!  Most of the editing interaction is with the browser so having that local was a dream.  Sending the updated cell contents and getting the results back only happens upon pressing ctrl-enter and typically only involves modest amounts of content (and only content) back and forth (no screen region updates etc) so the latency issues are comparatively negligible.  It was so much faster than trying to edit in a browser in a remote VNC session that I felt like a complete idiot for not having thought of this sooner, but I guess better late than never. :face_with_rolling_eyes:

elements.text: File this under "O for Obvious":  I've been working on a Pluto notebook at a very remote facility that has suboptimal Internet connectivity (low bandwidth and high latency) using Firefox in a VNC session running on a server at the remote facility from a VNC client on my laptop.  During a recent period of unusually sporadic connectedness, progress was extremely slow and painful.  Then it dawned on me (finally!) that I could create a port forwarding tunnel via SSH and connect from the browser on my laptop to the Pluto server running at the remote site through the port forwarding tunnel.  I'm no stranger to port forwarding, but I hadn't realized how beneficial it would be for Pluto notebooks.  It was a complete game changer!  Most of the editing interaction is with the browser so having that local was a dream.  Sending the updated cell contents and getting the results back only happens upon pressing ctrl-enter and typically only involves modest amounts of content (and only content) back and forth (no screen region updates etc) so the latency issues are comparatively negligible.  It was so much faster than trying to edit in a browser in a remote VNC session that I felt like a complete idiot for not having thought of this sooner, but I guess better late than never.

messages.text:
there is one interesting autocomplete question specific to Julia:

In OOP languages like Python, you can do `my_dataframe.<TAB>`  to see all the things that you can do with a dataframe, and this is a great way to learn about “what you can do with an object/package”.

In Julia, the function comes _before_ the object, so how can we achieve the same effect? If I have a `my_dataframe`  object in my notebook, how can I learn what I can do with it?

Write your suggestions to <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/issues/111>

messages.text: I'm working on some Pluto notebooks to serve as tutorials for students (of all ages!) to learn about some of the data products our team produces and some related domain specific concepts.  Is there a way to host notebooks such that users can access them, interact with the UI elements (sliders, select boxes, etc), see plots and other outputs update dynamically in response to their UI choices, and even look at the contents of the cells to see how they work, but NOT let them edit the contents of the cells (or only edit some cells)?  Is this type of thing being done in classroom settings already?

elements.text: I'm working on some Pluto notebooks to serve as tutorials for students (of all ages!) to learn about some of the data products our team produces and some related domain specific concepts.  Is there a way to host notebooks such that users can access them, interact with the UI elements (sliders, select boxes, etc), see plots and other outputs update dynamically in response to their UI choices, and even look at the contents of the cells to see how they work, but NOT let them edit the contents of the cells (or only edit some cells)?  Is this type of thing being done in classroom settings already?

messages.text:
To celebrate Pluto’s *1 year anniversary*, we are hosting a *two day mini conference* about… Pluto! It will be a place to share your fun notebooks and to *learn techniques from other Pluto users* and from Pluto’s designers.
Take a look our website to learn more!

 :balloon: <http://plutojl.org/plutocon2021|plutojl.org/plutocon2021>

*You can give a talk!*
It does not need to be _about_ Pluto, you can talk about anything exciting that you are working on, if you feel like the Pluto audience would be interested! To propose a talk, simply edit our website to add yourself to the list. If you’re not sure about your subject, or you don’t have time to prepare a talk, send us an email and we will figure it out! <mailto:fons@plutojl.org|fons@plutojl.org>

Looking forward to meeting you all!
xoxo the pluto team

If you’re not sure about your subject, or you don’t have time to prepare a talk, send us an email and we will figure it out!
fons@plutojl.org

Looking forward to meeting you all!
xoxo the pluto team

messages.text:
When defining variables in a begin/end block like:
```begin
  x = 1
  y = 2
end```
the value displayed is just `2`.  But if they are defined like:
```y = begin
  x = 1
  2
end```
then the value is displayed as `y = 2`.  Is there a general preference for one way vs the other?  I guess it depends on what the author wants to convey so maybe it's too context sensitive for a general preference, but I'd be curious to hear what others think.

  2
end
then the value is displayed as

messages.text:
well, the half of cpu cores is actually half of 2x cpu cores (because hyper threading) so you end up giving threads == # cpu cores. (which I believed is by design, according to the code comments)

when on a shared node environment, often the motherboard have 2+ cpu(s) so you end up giving me all cpu cores across *four* cpus which is not very efficient in terms of memory sharing to begin with.

there is a reason user sets `JULIA_NUM_THREADS` . Opened a <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/pull/990|PR> for further discussion.

four

cpus which is not very efficient in terms of memory sharing to begin with.

there is a reason user sets

PR
for further discussion.

messages.text: I have no problem with re-inventing the wheel for more flexibility / customization. But when user deliberately limits the resource, Pluto should have no reason to not respect it.

root.text: Pluto doesn't respect the JULIA_NUM_THREADAS environment variable for some reason?

elements.text: Pluto doesn't respect the JULIA_NUM_THREADAS environment variable for some reason?
I have no problem with re-inventing the wheel for more flexibility / customization. But when user deliberately limits the resource, Pluto should have no reason to not respect it.

messages.text:
I find the quality and maturity of Pluto to be very low, and I’m annoyed. However I do need to use it because of Computational Thinking. Here are two examples:

Several times in the last weeks I’ve had the UI loose connection with the kernel somehow. I may be able to write something on the UI, but nothing gets executed. When I kill Pluto on the REPL and re-start things, I see that latest things I wrote on the notebook are not saved.

Second is about the with_terminal(). I tried figuring out why my function is not working properly so I went to the trouble of copy-pasting the code that calls it to another cell, edited the cell so it properly calls that. Then I invoke the cell, verify that I can get some output, but because the internal code throws a MethodError, it no longer displays the output when I really need it. Ok, I try to look for the output in the actual terminal, but because the code is called by several cells in the notebook, I have way too much output. Then I edit the function name so the other cells don’t call it.

None of this would have been a problem with a Jupyter notebook.

elements.text:
I find the quality and maturity of Pluto to be very low, and I’m annoyed. However I do need to use it because of Computational Thinking. Here are two examples:

Several times in the last weeks I’ve had the UI loose connection with the kernel somehow. I may be able to write something on the UI, but nothing gets executed. When I kill Pluto on the REPL and re-start things, I see that latest things I wrote on the notebook are not saved.

Second is about the with_terminal(). I tried figuring out why my function is not working properly so I went to the trouble of copy-pasting the code that calls it to another cell, edited the cell so it properly calls that. Then I invoke the cell, verify that I can get some output, but because the internal code throws a MethodError, it no longer displays the output when I really need it. Ok, I try to look for the output in the actual terminal, but because the code is called by several cells in the notebook, I have way too much output. Then I edit the function name so the other cells don’t call it.

None of this would have been a problem with a Jupyter notebook.

messages.text: Especially given its age, I find the quality and maturity of Pluto amazing.  I run into roughly the same amount of issues as Jupyter, although with Jupyter I have to google "how to clear a Jupyter notebook from the command line" once/week because it choked on me.  I'm currently using Pluto to create *very* computation-heavy notebooks for a customer who doesn't have strong Julia skills.  I'm able to make a simple UI and hide most of the code and I don't have to deal with the overhead of making a full web app.

very

computation-heavy notebooks for a customer who doesn't have strong Julia skills.  I'm able to make a simple UI and hide most of the code and I don't have to deal with the overhead of making a full web app.

messages.text: I have a Pluto notebook with three cells.  The first cell creates an Array.  The second cell populates the Array.  The third cell computes a result based on the Array contents.  I find that changes made in the second cell (that change the  Array's contents) do not trigger the third cell to recompute the result.  I guess this is because the second cell is changing the contents of the Array, but the actual variable that references the Array is unchanged.  I've been able to work around this by also setting a dummy variable in the second cell (`pluto_opulate_trigger = nothing`) and then adding a no-op reference the dummy variable in the third cell.  This seems to work OK, but I was wondering: is there a better way to handle this situation?  If not, is there some sort of naming convention for such dummy variables?

elements.text: I have a Pluto notebook with three cells.  The first cell creates an Array.  The second cell populates the Array.  The third cell computes a result based on the Array contents.  I find that changes made in the second cell (that change the  Array's contents) do not trigger the third cell to recompute the result.  I guess this is because the second cell is changing the contents of the Array, but the actual variable that references the Array is unchanged.  I've been able to work around this by also setting a dummy variable in the second cell (
pluto_opulate_trigger = nothing

) and then adding a no-op reference the dummy variable in the third cell.  This seems to work OK, but I was wondering: is there a better way to handle this situation?  If not, is there some sort of naming convention for such dummy variables?

messages.text:
I think I see a trivial (but annoying) problem when using Pluto
`using` cells are executed before `import` cells
as a result,
```import Pkg;
Pkg.activate("/a/b/c")```
cell gets executed _after_ `using xyz` cell, when I first run my notebook
causing the xyz not found error

I think there should be a command in Pluto, something like `activate"/a/b/c"`, which gets executed before any other cell, when a notebook is started

messages.text:
_Hi everyone! *PlutoCon 2021* is coming soon, get excited!_
The conference will be held on *April 8-9*, and you can watch it live on the Julia Programming Language youtube channel.

<https://plutojl.org/plutocon2021>

If you would like to give a talk, get in touch during the next couple of days: <mailto:fons@plutojl.org|fons@plutojl.org>
Even if you are not giving a talk, *everyone is invited to upload their favorite notebooks to our _live demo page_*, which will run all notebooks with `@bind` as interactive web apps. There are some really cool submissions already! <https://plutocon2021-demos.netlify.app/>

messages.text:
We just released *Pluto 0.14*! This release is all about laying the groundwork for exciting new features, highlights include:
• An overhaul of Pluto’s networked state management (<https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/pull/710|#710>), which allows us to 
    ◦ implement exciting new features much more quickly in the future, like (<https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/pull/891|#891>), (<https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/pull/844|#844>) and (<https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/pull/437|#437>)
    ◦ dynamically switch between a static preview, a “slider server” and a live session, without having to refresh the browser (this technology powers <http://computationalthinking.mit.edu|computationalthinking.mit.edu> and <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/pull/811|#811> and <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/pull/988|#988>)
• Lots of stability improvements, fixed some race conditions
• “Soft interrupt” on Windows (<https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/pull/932|#932>)
The <https://github.com/fonsp/Pluto.jl/compare/v0.12.19...v0.14.0|git diff> tells us that this release will bring you:
• 38 merged pull requests from 19 contributors
• 160 commits
• 6000 additions and 3000 deletions to 103 files _(excluding computer-generated files)_
Enjoy! Thank you to everyone who contributed, through code changes, feedback or otherwise!

(just like PlutoUI!)

messages.text:
How breaking will it be when package management gets included into pluto? A major scenario I have in mind is `include("../startup.jl")` in notebooks, with startup.jl in the project directory with something like
```import Pkg
Pkg.activate(...)

using ...
using ...```
Will it continue working?

elements.text: How breaking will it be when package management gets included into pluto? A major scenario I have in mind is
include("../startup.jl")
in notebooks, with startup.jl in the project directory with something like

import Pkg
Pkg.activate(...)

using ...
using ...
Will it continue working?

messages.text:
Bottom line, can I undo the deletion of a lot of cells? I can't figure it out.

I still have the session open. I had one notebook which had enough things that I wanted to break it up into two different notebooks. I saved it to a new location and then went about deleting the things I didn't need. Apparently, this does not generate a new file but rather changes the name of the file and all updates go to that file (old file is gone). I know if you delete a cell you can `undo` for a short amount of time, but a significant amount of time has passed. Git repo did show a deleted file, but I didn't commit my changes recently enough to be useful.

If this isn't possible, perhaps others will see this and be forewarned

elements.text:
Bottom line, can I undo the deletion of a lot of cells? I can't figure it out.

I still have the session open. I had one notebook which had enough things that I wanted to break it up into two different notebooks. I saved it to a new location and then went about deleting the things I didn't need. Apparently, this does not generate a new file but rather changes the name of the file and all updates go to that file (old file is gone). I know if you delete a cell you can
undo

for a short amount of time, but a significant amount of time has passed. Git repo did show a deleted file, but I didn't commit my changes recently enough to be useful.

If this isn't possible, perhaps others will see this and be forewarned

messages.text: Hello! I have to use PyCall to generate a dataset in a Pluto notebook, but it looks like whenever the cell with the py"""....""" command gets rerun memory usage increases, until eventually I run out of memory. Is this normal? I can't figure it out.

messages.text: I’m really excited about PlutoSliderServer. I didn’t have luck setting it up yet, but I can’t complain too much about an unregistered package with a README filled with TODOs. Installation is a huge impediment to my colleagues using my work, and being able to turn a notebook into a web app is going to be killer.

elements.text: I’m really excited about PlutoSliderServer. I didn’t have luck setting it up yet, but I can’t complain too much about an unregistered package with a README filled with TODOs. Installation is a huge impediment to my colleagues using my work, and being able to turn a notebook into a web app is going to be killer.
